commentBody: Fastest Saturday I‚Äôve ever done. Just me? I enjoyed the puzzle still.

Pleasant puzzle. I liked ARGONAUTS and SCATTER PLOTS. Set a new personal best (under 10 minutes). Yesterday I was 6 minutes over my average, so go figure. Difficulty levels are all over and so is my performance :-)

Very breezy Saturday. I think being familiar with Caitlin Clark, WandaVision and being a frequent user of the mentioned dog meme helped get me off to a flying start

This was faster than all of my Wed-Fri times this week!

Fairly fast Friday for me. A few interesting clues, but none challenging. My first thoughts for answers were all correct, and  the little "obscure trivia" was gently crossed. There should be lots of happy newer solvers today. Veterans will be seeking a  Saturday or two in the archive.
Personal best for Saturday - and well below my Friday personal best.

Despite a plethora of general knowledge (trivia if you will) this one came together very quickly  for me.  I‚Äôm sure some will curse it, and I sympathize, but it just happened to be in my wheelhouse.

GIANTSTEPS was a gimme.  Although it‚Äôs viewed as seminal album in the development of Coltrane‚Äôs career, it‚Äôs not one of my favorite of his albums.  I prefer his Africa Brass Sessions and A Love Supreme.  For those who don‚Äôt like the experimental Coltrane his Ballads album and his collaboration with Johnny Hartman are sublime mainstream jazz.

UPDIKE was also a gimme.  His Gertrude And Claudius, a retelling of Hamlet from the perspective of his uncle and mother, is quite clever.
Fast and fun
Breezy and fun for a new PB. Might have been used as a Friday.
I kept expecting to get stuck on something, (a regular Saturday occurrence), but was pleasantly surprised to find myself filling in that ‚Äús‚Äù in nasa for the easy completion.

I don't know any puns about a pi√±ata, but I can take a swing at it.

(Well, that's just fine and candy.)
I was going to call the MANSAMU_A/NA_A crossing a Natick, especially since I'm usually quite knowledgeable on Greek mythology. I started to brute force it, but I got to S, it was just egg on my face.

"Shortening for a city that omits 'onto'" is an utterly horrendous clue. How about "state that starts with IOW" for IOWA? 

What happened to Saturdays not being clued and filled identically to Tuesdays? I know the answer is "we get more money this way", but come on
Quick solve.  Cluing was a bit on-the-nose.

Pretty breezy Saturday, nothing too exceptional but nothing to complain about. I enjoyed the clues for ROOTCANAL and PI√ëATA the most. Can anyone explain the THISISFINE meme? Is there some double entendre I‚Äôm not getting?
I‚Äôm embarrassed  (RED faced) to say how long it took me to understand why OHIO would be a RED state (outside of politics) despite living in the home of the Cincinnati REDS. I guess while cute enough for a crossword I would always say REDS state. 
Since not much else to expound on for me I will take the rest of my time to extol Paul ANKA. I had the privilege of going to his concert a year or two ago so he would have been, I suppose, 82? I thought it would be mostly to just say I‚Äôd seen the guy, I mean how much could a crooner have left in him when he recorded his first song in 1956? Man, let me tell you, it was one of the best concerts I can remember and certainly one of the most energetic. The guy never stopped running around for a moment and belted like he was 18. Plus I really didn‚Äôt realize the volume of hits and memorable songs he has written for others decade after decade. Just a masterful guy, and I HAD NO IDEA!

Thanks to this Saturday puzzle, I now have a new longest 6-day streak.
ScatterPLOT and DepthCHARTS are a nice pair of longest answers in this puzzle.
Giant Steps and Blue Cheese... something funky, perhaps.
Hope everyone had an enjoyable solve.

Fun and fast one! I really like the GIANTSTEPS on top of the GARDENPATH, and IOWA and OHIO crossing. My husband is in IOWA this weekend for work, which is not an unusual occurrence with his business. Of course, I'm always SAD when he's away, but IOWA has been very good to us‚Äîeven if its pigs do outnumber its people. 

I like that 11D meme, though it feels more and more apt to me lately... I think of that poor little pup often. NOTOKAY. 

There were very few immediate gimmes for me today so I thought it was going to be a toughie, but I finished almost 30% faster than average. That wasn't on my BINGOCARD but it works out well for me today/tomorrow as I have loads of things I should do tomorrow, even if I wish I could be an IDLER. 

Cheers to the weekend, however much you're up to!  üòä

I thought it was going to be faster. Scatterplot, Bingocard, Shortstop all easy peasy. Then the NE hung me up. 2 minutes over my average. Fun that ADDSUP, NET, BINGO CARD and SHORT STOP cross  SCATTERPLOT. Sandlot for a short stop creates a plot scattered‚Ä¶ I could keep going round and round to the ground. STOP ME NOW!!!!!
Actually a money related puzzle in general (THRIFT AND MANSAMUSA). And keeps my 2,276 day solvers streak going

Fun puzzle, the first Saturday I solved since July.

Most of the puzzle was very rewardingly "Figure-outable" but there were a few regions which really hung me up.  Right in the middle, the crossing of IOC/DOC/DES.  IOC and DES I'd never heard of and DOC threw me off because it's not really an image format, I was thinking PNG/GIF/JPG on that track.

Then since I also had not heard of MANSAMUSA a few of the not tough but sorta ambiguous crossing clues threw me off a while.
Nothing interesting to say so here's the Wikipedia article on Mansa Musa if anyone is interested. I believe he is considered the richest person to ever live. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mansa_Musa

TIL - a whole bunch of stuff. 

Eventually got everything with the crosses. A few of the long answers fell letter by letter and not in wordy clumps. In the end, pretty much on my Saturday average. 

As my son likes to tease me, ‚ÄúCrossword puzzles are easy. You only need to know half the answers!‚Äù

His better half knows ALL the answers. Which is pretty intimidating. To fill her time while waiting for me to catch up, she takes a run at Queen Bee.

In answer to the question OKAY?, my two-year-old nephew almost always said nOKAY.  Impressive early command of the concept of language.  They learn incredibly fast, and I thought that one was very cool.
For 21D I actually had to consult a football depth chart for a sports podcast I am doing with my friends, so I was happily primed for answering that!

Saturday puzzles are always difficult for me, and this one did not disappoint. I feel like I kept the lookups to a minimum, though, so I think it all ADDS UP. 

Not loving the ROOT CANAL reference, though. Baby  Australian Critter had 10 teeth removed yesterday, and he‚Äôs still felling the effects. And when he‚Äôs in pain, I‚Äôm in pain. Maybe we both just need to embrace the mantra: ‚ÄúTHIS IS FINE‚Ä¶‚Äù

Sam says: 23D. I‚Äôve only ever seen UTE used in reference to a person or a people, but through this clue I have learned about the sport UTE, which seems to be part S.U.V., part pickup truck ‚Äî the centaur of cars. Sam, do you mean this? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K6qGwmXZtsE

Just got back from an evening of musical theater with my wife.  (Took notes for Andrzej, of course.)  So I am a little late to the party, and the first thing I did after getting home, of course, was the puzzle.  

It went quite fast, even for a Saturday, and I commented that it was an easy puzzle to my wife, who doesn't do crosswords.  She said, or you're the smartest guy on earth.  I said, yes, of course I am, I married you, dear.  But the stats page says it's "Very Easy."

MANSAMUSAn kind of character.  IHADNOIDEA that the lack of THRIFT by one BRO making SHORTSTOPS in a country, dropping a LOTTO gold throughout his STAY, could wreck an economy, but it TSO, because it all ADDSUP.

Thank you, Ryan, IOWA lot to your puzzle.

This was a very weird puzzle for me. I was done with most of it in Tuesday time, disbelieving how straightforward the clues seemed, especially on the right/Eastern side of the grid.

However, the left/West side, and especially the NW corner, came close to defeating me. In the end I managed to fill the grid without googling, and in a time shorter than I usually get on Fridays, but a lot of guesses were involved, and I don't understand some of what I ultimately entered.

The column explained R-V guy to me (a quite obnoxious clue, that, IMO), and it confirmed my suspicion about Sport UTE (it just sounds so wrong... But us Polish people rarely shorten words, so most abbreviations feel jarring to me).

I have no idea why SHORT STOP is one who's off-base.

I had to guess OHIO (and IOWA). Why is it a "red state"? Are Ohio Reds a sport team or something?

There was something perverse about using the French "au poivre" and the American misnomer (of sorts) of "entree" in the same sentence. Because surely "steak au poivre" is not a French starter?

Roquefort as BLUE CHEESE was a gimme. Before 1989 the shelves in Polish (state-owned) shops were mostly empty, and if there was something for sale, it was of one variety (one yellow cheese, one white cheese, etc.) Democracy and market economy meant privately owned shops with ever improving stock. Roquefort was the first blue cheese to be offered, as I recall.

@dutchiris

Thank you for the poodle story yesterday üê©üòÉ. I only saw it just now.

Speedy Saturday certainly, but still more challenging and more fun than yesterday's.  (Still how I long for a theme though.)

I wanted "red state" to be "rare", but no.  Ohio?  Surely not just because of an electoral vote?  It must be something more clever -- I'll look it up in a minute.

I guess I'm so used to being annoyed by sports clues that I didn't even much notice.  Depth chart?  Okay sure if you say so.   Didn't know the Mansa person.  Even so, in aggregate this all felt more Wednesday-ish....
theres a ripple in the force when this young jedi solves a saturday in 20.

Before I read the comments, I'm assuming everyone is going to say how easy this was, but I'm not gonna let it get me down today. I'm so happy that I got a gold for the first time on a Saturday. :) 

I solved the Saturday 11/8/2025 New York Times Daily Crossword in 44:34!

This is one of the most straightforwardly clued Saturday puzzles I can recall, which made it a fairly quick solve.
But today I learned about Mansa Musa and what the capital of Bangladesh are.

I look forward to some clever misdirection on Saturday so I was a little disappointed that it was quite straightforward. I loved the clue for PI√ëATA. 

Wasn‚Äôt familiar with the dog meme so I looked it up. I don‚Äôt get it.

I didn't know MANSA MUSA and wondered who the mythological person NA_A might be.  Testing different letters in my head gave a few that sounded possible.  When I got to NASA, it was a big "doh!" moment.

Otherwise, smooth sailing.

THIS IS FINE is perfect in these dumpster fire times.
Upper left corner was a bear. Couldn‚Äôt finish. Enjoyed the rest.

Whenever possible, I try to linger a bit and look over the grid upon completion, because sweet serendipities often pop out, capping off the solve with loveliness, like dessert.

Today, for instance:
‚Ä¢	Contradictory cross of SHORT STOP and STAY.
‚Ä¢	USA beginning one answer (USARMY) and ending its cross (MANSAMUSA).
‚Ä¢	GARDEN PATH, which has both a beautiful and ugly connotation.
‚Ä¢	Lower-case places ‚Äì DIKE, GARDEN, CANAL, PLOT ‚Äì balanced by upper-case places IOWA, OAHU, RENO, DHAKA.
‚Ä¢	PuzzPair¬© of I SAID (as in ‚ÄúI Am‚Ä¶ I Said‚Äù) and nearby NEIL (as in Diamond).
 
So, not only a bouncy brain-pleasing solve with answers that pinged thoughts, images, and memories, but also a sweet finish of lovely finds.  In other words, a splendid outing.  Thank you, Ryan!

Enjoyed this one a lot, even if I would have liked it even more if it had lasted twice as long :). Smiled when I saw NASA ‚Äîlike @Steven M I was all ready to call ‚ÄúNatick!‚Äù before realizing the misdirect. 

Thanks Ryan. Please get another in the queue ‚Äî but don‚Äôt be afraid to dial up the difficulty a bit!
Should have swapped yesterday and today‚Äôs puzzles. Today was lovely, but I think would have made for a gentler weekend opener than the torture fest that was yesterday.

It seems a lot of people whizzed through this puzzle. I was not one of them...

However (fanfare...) I did get a baseball answer right. at last! üòÉ
Hate it when Friday and Saturday are the wrong way round

For once my years of watching sports pays off. I'm still physically recovering from the Wicked puzzle last week. Happy Saturday to all!

I must also take a moment to "cheers!" all of the wonderful posters in this forum. The Spelling Bee forum is like being swatted with a ruler by the nun teaching me in 2nd grade, where this forum is like an institution of higher learning where thoughts are embraced.  Time for mimosas!

Great to see ‚ÄúGiant Steps,‚Äù clued.  Made in 1960, just before Trane formed his legendary quartet, it‚Äôs a seminal jazz album.  I‚Äôm sure memorizing his solo on the title tune is still mandatory for aspiring saxophonists.  Two other tracks on the album, the gentle ballad, Naima, and the blues, Cousin Mary, also have become jazz standards.

That was a fun and accessible Saturday puzzle. 

My only doubt was cluing BINGO CARD as an accessory.
The link for this column disappeared more than a couple weeks ago from my NYT app. Why?

In the "TIL" column:

When I had AR___ to start 4-Down, I confidently put in ARachnidS, remembering the story of the weaving competition between Athena and Arachne.  Even though I knew that spiders aren't cephalopods ("head-foots"??? Try to remember to keep your cephalopods distinct from your gastropods [snails and the like; "stomach-foots"]).
But who knew that there were a family of octopuses called ARGONAUTS???
Today I learned.
They're awfully cute, as octopus go.  
Octopuses [sic] are amazing!

And while we're on the topic of Greek mythology, I thoroughly enjoyed the "Artemis" misdirect.

But don't get me started on MANSA MUSA, great Malian leader of the 14th century, perhaps the richest king that ever lived???
Never heard of him.
I'm impressed with the number of commenters who were familiar with his exploits.  I certainly need to work on the enormous lacuna in my knowledge of sub-Saharan African history.
So, today I learned that MANSA was his title and that MUSA is the Arabic form of Moses (Moshe in Hebrew).
That's a start, I guess.
Clever cluing, but this was way, way too easy for a Saturday. C'mon, NYT.

Good morning! This one was in my wheelhouse. I considered some sort of sculling misdirect for 35A before FRATBRO fell in. My last letter was the S in NASA - a guess! Like others, I was expecting a Greek deity - thanks for a good chuckle.

Disappointing offering for a Saturday. Seemed very straightforward, with a lot of dull fill and clunky (or much too direct) cluing ("Roquefort, e.g.").

Hard to enjoy stuff like ISAID, IHEARIT ("You're not just imagining that tone"), IHADNOIDEA, RARESTAMP.

"Shortening for a city that omits 'onto'" for TOR. C'mon.

A rare day when I felt the editorial team dropped the ball.
Best thing about this smooth solve is the reminder to dig out those Coltrane LPs.

I once lived in an apartment in the Clifton area of Cincinnati--across the street from a once-grand mansion that was a FRAT house.  One came to the conclusion that a FRAT BRO is something akin to a slime mold, only not as intelligent.  (Awaiting stories about your fraternity that helped widows and orphans, adopted stray animals, and shoveled snow iin the blizzard of '75.)  

DHubby helped me with SCATTER PLOT after I had SCAT and wanted a boost.  
NAUTILUSi and OCTOPUSi....neither seemed likely.  Very surprised that Odysseus went a-sailing on a cephalopod; must have been a big'un!

Maybe one had to have seen the ?cartoon?movie clip? Of the dog to appreciate 11D...  
59A and 60A...wow.  Srsly??  Worth it?

Well... not all that easy for me, of course. More than a few answers that were never come to me without some crosses. And... had to look up a couple of things. No big deal - that's just me. And, of course a puzzle find today. A Sunday from April 7, 1991 by Valerie Meunier with the title "Cross examination." LOTS of theme answers in that one, and yeah - each of them crossed another theme answer. Some examples: WHOSSORRYNOW WHATSINANAME WHATSUPDOC HOWAMIDOING WHOSTHERE AINTSHESWEET WHATSCOOKING WHOSONFIRST HOWNOWBROWNCOW HOWDOILOVETHEE WHATSMYLINE Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=4/7/1991&g=39&d=A ....

I feel like I need to apologize to my late father for not realizing that "Red State?" was a baseball, not a political, reference. (I had a major ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è moment when I got it.) He grew up in Ohio, and he passed both his love of baseball and his Reds fandom on to me. (While I am still a huge baseball fan, I was wooed away from the Reds by the family I married into.)
lots of non-words and proper nouns today

Alas, poor Natick! I knew him not.

Ye gods and little catfishes, crossing Mali history with Greek mythology, that's a bit much. YMMV.


Otherwise, THIS IS FINE.

I hope that the editors and writers of these columns have a good long think about what constitutes ‚Äútricky‚Äù clues and can adjust accordingly.

This was fine [insert meme]. I did not really enjoy it but that‚Äôs okay.

Happy Saturday!

Pretty good puzzle, and was able to finish it without peeking at answers.  The long down clues and a number of short crosses helped with the fill-ins of some of the tougher entries.
Anyone else have BRIDGE GAME for 26 D? I still say that would be a great clue/answer pair.

A perfect Saturday puzzle for me. It took a long time, during most of which there were large seas of white space all over the grid. With my amassing enough finger- and toeholds, the white space shriveled down to the last consonant in MANSA MUSA, a man I'd never met before (but who Britannica labels "the wealthiest person in history"). So it was a question of running the alphabet. This puzzle needed every fibre of my solving ability.
Lol, Stu.  Well done.

Excellent! Once I got a toehold in the southeast, it was off to the races. A nice romp with a quality meme, Coltrane, and a forehead slap - what‚Äôs not to like? And a bonus of finishing over a full minute faster than yesterday‚Äôs gem. Thank you!
MANSA MUSA? I think he plays for Chelsea.

Great puzzle, Ryan Judge. Just crunchy enough to make me feel very smart about finishing it in a fairly good time. MANSA MUSA was a complete unknown to me but got him from crosses eventually and then looked him up for a little explanation. Please get to work on more puzzles for us üëèüèªüëèüèª
This was an enjoyable puzzle, but quite easy for a Saturday. I think the cluing could have been more challenging.
Any puzzle with a Trane clue is pure perfection!! Mansa Musa is a delicious bonus:)
Sometimes I feel like a wimp for reading the hints but today I'm glad I saved myself another hour. I was deeply committed to toothache and nothing was coming together in SE corner üòí

Sometimes the key to a good nerd puzzle is the confidence to admit that I don‚Äôt know everything. 

The world is good. I can admit my lack of knowledge.  I can learn something new.  And in the process see the results of a creation that required the first step on the path to wisdom.

Certainly not my finest (sub 1) hour. A few clues I wasn‚Äôt a fan of at all and an almost-Natick for me, but the fault still lies with me! I couldn‚Äôt seem to find my footing for a time and as per usual, back-and-forthed on more than a few answers. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure nobody calls it BRIECHEESE?‚Äù and a brief dalliance with CBD/THC/LSD left me on quite the comedown. I‚Äôm definitely learning some good habits after around a month or so of playing though, and every day is a school day for me, even if those lessons are just the acronyms of various American organisations!

The classic cinema nerd in me was excited to be reminded of the ARGONAUTS, so that was my personal highlight, my only real disappointment was that I thought I‚Äôd found an excellent pun in the SE, because where better to work if you enjoy running drills than at BOOTCAMPS?

Just piping up to complain about the 6-down clue: Shortening for a city that omits "onto"

I ordinarily appreciate clues that require a bit of interpretation but for me this went a bit too far. 

Other than that, the world is a perfect place... isn't it?

Re 56A: When I went to have a ROOT CANAL around 15 years ago, the (excellent) dentist offered a large selection of movies I could watch to help me relax during the procedure. I chose Finding Nemo, because I had seen it before and knew I would enjoy it. I totally forgot that the movie contained this scene: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IYEQCDt5PYY

Nice shout out to the TORonto ARGONAUTS of the Canadian Football League
This one is ok if you like US baseball, I guess. Too many gimmes -- SLAT, PSAT, NASA.... And why is GI Joe constantly popping up?

The cluing and answers were quite fun. I solved it far too quickly somehow. And after weeks of cribbing and getting irritated about Saturdays being too hard, I never thought I'd become one of those people who think that this should have been a bit harder ü§Øüôâ
Such a fun solve! Found it on the easier side but no bad clues. Great way to start my weekend

Witty clues. It was a very quick solve, yes, but I don't mind an occasional easy one. It adds to the variety. And I have enjoyed the variety recently. 

I want to thank the editors for gradually reintroducing difficulty in a way that both those of us who developed our cravings in a more difficult era (yes, those cravings are your fault, NYT!), along with those who came on board during the more easy era, all can be confident we will get our respective fixes soon. (Some people derive their joy by complaining, and I think you are keeping them happy, too.)

A first for me today for a Saturday: only one thing in this grid I had not heard of before, the dog meme. And actually, though I had heard of the Mali Empire ruler in passing, it was much too long ago for it to be any help with the spelling. Also, I didn't know about the gold. I'm going to spend the time I would usually spend on a solve to look that up.

Thank you again, Shortz and crew. I can't imagine the work that must go into selecting and editing these.

Okay, you are the only games community that I participate in and I just have to share this crazy, crazy thing that happened with Wordle. There are no spoilers here! But my mind is just blown!

Wordle 1,603 4/6

Not that impressive, right!? But ever since Wordle began, I chose a starting word that I use all the time. I've said I'm going to keep using this word until it shows up as the answer, which would be a Wordle in one, of course.

But today, feeling a little sassy, for literally the first time, I just picked the first other word that came to my mind and went with it, not even noticing in my brazeness that three of the letters are in the same place as in my usual starting word.... 

No spoilers, but as it turns out, my dream of my normal starting word being the actual answer finally came true today... But of course, I didn't get it until the 4th try. So much for sassiness! 

I suppose there's a lesson to be learned there, but instead I'm just going to say, cue the Alanis Morissette song....  Har!

(To a Frederick Loewe melody)

Some days you get the puzzle; other days, the puzzle gets you. It's the main reason I look forward to weekends now. Some here mentioned that pi√±ata made them think about their childhood parties.

He was a quiet man who didn‚Äôt share a lot. I think those pi√±atas were one of the ways he showed us how much he loved us.

@Teresa

Team names (and other nouns of all ilks) often revert to singular form when being used as an attributive noun, which is to say, placed before another noun to modify is as if it were an adjective.

That's why we have Yankee Stadium, Dodger Stadium, Angel Stadium, etc.  When there's a chance of confusion, the plural form may be used, such as (the now gone) Giants Stadium.  I guess the team didn't want people thinking it was just a really big stadium.

It's the Astrodome.  Not the Astrosdome.

The franks served at Dodger Stadium are famously called Dodger dogs, not Dodgers dogs.

So, "Yankee state," "Dodger state," etc., would also work for me.  Add the question mark to point to wordplay, and I think the clue is fine.

If you mean, is my data included in their stats, then yes.  But anyone who subscribes is included.  I just think that most of the people who care that much about stats are already good solvers, and have gotten past the "Can I even solve this?" stage.

I notice that the median time does go up later into the night and the next morning, signifying that the first solvers are also the most experienced.  Most of the time, when I open the site, my solve time is slower than the posted median, but rather quickly that median rises to the point that I'm faster than the later numbers.

I think of these statistics like pars in golf.  Just because a hole is a par 3 doesn't mean that most people will shoot 3 on it.  It's what a good golfer might be able to shoot, and it sets a guideline about how that hole compares to the others.

@John

I knew someone would find a math error.  I should have gotten up to find a pencil and paper to do it right.  But that stuff is in the part of the house where my wife is residing, and we're trying (unsuccessfully) to isolate from one another due to illness.

Let's go through it step by step.  We agree that gold is about 19.3 g /cc or 19.3 kg / liter. Right?

And we agree a basketball is about 7.5 liters.  Then the mass of gold the size of a basketball would be 7.5 x 19,300 g = 145,000 g or 145 kg, or about 320 pounds.  So, yeah, it would take a little less than 7 basketballs to make a ton.  Thanks for checking me.  Still a volume you could easily carry in the trunk of your car.

Concerning Indy: you suggest that the dimensions of the golden idol was 30cm x 20cm x 10cm (I'm assuming you meant centimeters).  That's 6000 cc, (not 600 cc).  Or about 6 liters.  Thats about 6 liter x (19.3 kg/liter) = 115 kg, or about 255 pounds.

I had one (1) root canal, over 50 years ago, and I was NOT anesthetized. It was the most painful experience of my life. The dentist insisted I had to be numb and it was all in my head. He was a quack.
